variant.question: You are departing an aerodrome (600 ft AMSL, QNH 1012 hPa) and proceed to another airfield (150 ft AMSL) with the same QNHAfter landing, which barometric setting on the altimeter makes it again indicate 600 ft?

options.text: pressure measured in the standard atmosphere.
altitude indicated with QFE set on the altimeter.
altitude indicated with QNH set on the altimeter.

variant.question: Without re-adjusting the barometric setting of the altimeter, it will under-read when

options.text: flying from a low pressure area into a high pressure area.
flying in headwind with constant barometric pressure.
flying in tailwind with constant barometric pressure.
flying from a high pressure area into a low pressure area.

variant.question: When flying in cold air (colder than standard atmosphere), the altimeter will

options.text: show the actual height above ground.
show the actual height above the sea level.

The pressure altitude is the altitude corresponding

options.text: in standard atmosphere, to the pressure PS prevailing at this point.
in standard atmosphere, to the reference pressure PS.
in ambient atmosphere, to the pressure PS prevailing at this point.
in ambient atmosphere, to the reference pressure PS.

The altimeter is based upon the same principle as
The altitude indicated on board an aircraft flying in an atmosphere where all the atmosphere layers below the aircraft are cold is

options.text: the same as the real altitude.

variant.question: The density altitude is

options.text: the altitude of the standard atmosphere on which the density is equal to the actual density of the atmosphere.
the temperature altitude corrected for the difference between the real temperature and the standard temperature.
the pressure altitude corrected for the relative density prevailing at this point.
the pressure altitude corrected for the density of air at this point.

variant.question:
An altimeter contains one or more aneroid capsules
Inside these capsules is

options.text: a very low residual pressure and outside is static pressure.
static pressure and outside a very low residual pressure.
dynamic pressure and outside is static pressure.
static pressure and outside is dynamic pressure.

variant.question: The altimeter is supplied with
When flying in cold air (colder than standard atmosphere), indicated altitude is:

options.text: the same as the true altitude.

variant.question: The advantages of a servo altimeter over a sensitive altimeter include...

options.text: being independent of the aircraft power supply.

variant.question: An aircraft is equipped with one altimeter that is compensated for position error and another one altimeter that is not. Assuming all other factors are equal, during a straight symmetrical flight:

options.text: the greater the speed, the greater the error between the two altimeters.
the lower the speed, the greater the error between the two altimeters.
the error between the two altimeters does not depend on the speed.
the greater the speed, the lower the error between the two altimeters.

variant.question: GPS indications (without augmentation) may sometimes provide an inaccurate representation of altitude. Why is that?

options.text: The mathematical model used by the GPS is a very close approximation to, rather than a complete match with, the actual shape of the Earth.
If there is an insufficient number of satellites in view, this can result in missing information and inconsistencies with the ephemeris data.
The height of the ionosphere interferes with the path lengths of the radio waves.
If there are too many satellites in view, the excess information fails to coincide with that in the Almanac.

options.text: It doesn’t rely on aircraft electrics.

LOWER than ISA, the aircraft will be HIGHER than the altimeter reading.
HIGHER than ISA and the QNH IS HIGHER than 1013.25 hPa, the aircraft will be LOWER than the altimeter reading.
